results.question: What is the maximum power output of the Haliade-X offshore wind turbine platform?
results.expected_answer: Up to 18 MW (with models ranging from 12 MW to 18 MW)

[Note: This answer includes information from web search.]

The Haliade‑X offshore wind turbine platform has a maximum power output rating of 12 megawatts (MW) for its standard configuration, with newer variants designed to reach up to 14 MW under optimal conditions.

citations.excerpt: Standard Haliade-X rated capacity: 12 MW; upgraded version up to 14 MW.

results.actual_answer:
[Note: This answer includes information from web search.]

results.question: How much annual energy can a single Haliade-X 14.7 MW turbine generate?
results.expected_answer: Up to 76 GWh annually, enough to power 20,000 European households

Based on typical offshore wind capacity factors of 50–60%, a single Haliade‑X 14.7 MW turbine would generate roughly 65–75 GWh of electricity per year (≈14.7 MW × 8760 h × 0.55). This estimate is derived from industry‑average performance metrics because no specific annual generation figure for the Haliade‑X was located in the knowledge graph or web sources.

results.question: How does a GE Vernova H-class combined-cycle plant's CO2 emissions compare to a coal-fired plant?
results.expected_answer: 60% less CO2 emissions compared to a similarly sized coal-fired asset
results.actual_answer:
[Note: This answer includes information from web search.]

A GE Vernova H‑class combined‑cycle plant emits considerably less carbon dioxide than a typical coal‑fired power plant. Because the H‑class design achieves thermal efficiencies around 60 % and uses advanced turbine and heat‑recovery systems, its CO₂ intensity is roughly 350–400 g CO₂ per kilowatt‑hour (kWh). In contrast, a conventional coal‑fired plant generally releases about 820–1,000 g CO₂ per kWh. This means the combined‑cycle facility produces approximately 50–60 % fewer CO₂ emissions for the same electricity output.

These figures are based on typical emission factors reported for high‑efficiency natural‑gas combined‑cycle units and average coal‑fired generation profiles in recent environmental assessments.

citations.source_title: GE Power – H-Class Combined Cycle Plant Technical Overview
citations.excerpt: The H‑class combined‑cycle plant achieves up to 60% thermal efficiency and emits approximately 350–400 g CO₂/kWh, roughly half the emissions of a typical coal plant.

citations.source_title: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency – Emissions from Electricity Generation
citations.excerpt: Average CO₂ emission factor for coal‑fired electricity generation is about 820–1,000 g/kWh, whereas natural‑gas combined‑cycle plants emit around 350–450 g/kWh.
